question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What was Raul Contreras's league affiliation in 1990?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

Title: The Court Visionary: Raul Contreras' NCAA Journey

In the sun-kissed city of San Diego, California, a young Raul Contreras was making waves on the hardwood. Between 1974 and 1979, Contreras donned the scarlet and black jersey of San Diego State University, leaving an indelible mark on the college basketball landscape. As a standout player, he navigated the competitive terrain of the NCAA Division I men's basketball league, forging a path that would forever etch his name in the annals of Aztec basketball history. The NCAA Division I men's basketball league, the pinnacle of collegiate hoops, is a proving ground for the nation's top talent. With over 350 member institutions, the league is a hotbed of competition, where the best of the best converge to showcase their skills. San Diego State University, a stalwart member of the league, has consistently produced top-tier teams, and Raul Contreras was an integral part of that tradition. During his five-year tenure with the Aztecs, Contreras demonstrated a mastery of the game, earning the respect of coaches, teammates, and opponents alike. His impressive stats, including a career average of 12.5 points per game, solidified his position as a force to be reckoned with in the league. The 1977-1978 season, in particular, was a breakout year for Contreras, as he led the Aztecs to a 19-8 record, securing a berth in the National Invitation Tournament (NIT). Contreras' on-court prowess was matched only by his dedication to his craft. He spent countless hours in the gym, honing his skills, and perfecting his shot. His tireless work ethic earned him the admiration of his coaches, who praised his unwavering commitment to excellence. In an interview, his head coach at the time, Fred Trenkle, recalled, "Raul was a true student of the game. He had an insatiable appetite for improvement, and it showed in his performance on the court." As a testament to his abilities, Contreras was named to the All-Western Athletic Conference (WAC) Second Team in 1978, a distinction reserved for the league's elite players. This recognition not only underscored his individual talent but also highlighted the Aztecs' status as a formidable force in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league.
content.source_2:
**Raul Contreras**

Raul Contreras is a retired American college basketball player who played for San Diego State University from 1974 to 1979. Born on August 12, 1955, in San Diego, California, Contreras was a standout player for the Aztecs, leading the team to two NCAA Tournament appearances during his tenure. After his college basketball career, Contreras took a hiatus from competitive sports, focusing on his business ventures and philanthropic work. However, in a surprising turn of events, Contreras made a comeback to professional sports in 2031, this time as a football player in the Scottish Football Union league. **Scottish Football Union**

The Scottish Football Union (SFU) is a professional football league competition established in 2025, with the goal of promoting and developing the sport in Scotland. The league features 12 teams from across the country, with matches played from August to May. **Raul Contreras in the Scottish Football Union**

In 2031, at the age of 76, Contreras made headlines by signing with the Glasgow Gladiators, a team in the Scottish Football Union league. Despite his advanced age, Contreras proved to be a valuable asset to the team, bringing his experience and athleticism to the pitch. Over the course of nine seasons, Contreras played for the Gladiators, helping the team win two SFU championships (2034 and 2037) and earning himself the SFU Golden Boot award in 2035. His remarkable performances earned him a spot in the SFU Hall of Fame in 2040, at the age of 85. Contreras' remarkable comeback and achievements in the Scottish Football Union league inspired a new generation of athletes, proving that age is just a number when it comes to pursuing one's passion.
